this is what believers cling to. they deliberately avoid defining god. even concluding that god cannot be defined, or that god is beyond the scope of words and concepts, or some other abstract useless excuse like that. they settle for a definition-free god because its the only way they can protect their god from being disproven. go figure

 
 I suppose some get very vague about what god is or isn't, and then there is nothing of substance there. Still, for the vast majority of believers, their god is something on a much more human scale with human feelings. It's a projection of human nature on to divinity. 
 
 I can't formulate a scientific argument against a god of the deists or pantheists, because there's nothing there to counter using reason and empiricism, but the Abrahamic god, that's one we can get our teeth into.

 I used to sit in church and wonder what was meant when the pastor would say, "God is Love." Never could figure that out.

Why should you expect God to do all your dirty work for you.
 
 Why should you tar God with your own brush ?
 
 Look on it as if God is a teacher watching his pupils make all sorts of mistakes but if they are truly to learn then they have to sort them out themselves. The guidance is there whether we follow it is up to us

 I have to take issue with you position. It is just not that simple! "A teacher watching his pupils make all sorts of mistakes"!? A teacher does not allow his students to kill or to torture others or to kill in his name, etc., etc.. Do you HONESTLY believe that a good and loving god would allow killing on such as massive scale as we have in just Iraq at the present? What is the lesson he he trying to teach? If there was a god and he indeed was a teacher, this place of ours would be a better place to live.

Millions of people used to think the earth was flat, and that George Bush was fit to be president, but reason has talked most out of it. This isn't a numbers game with the deity with the most believers being the most real! And no. Poseidon and the Graeco-Roman pantheon were not attributes of the Judeo-Christian-Islamic deity. It used to be you'd be burned at the stake for suggesting such heresy (and in some places still would be)! :)

 Alas, humans aren't children, and god isn't a parent, he's a projection of human failings and desires.
 
 Can I better the Sermon on the Mount? Probably not (though it is not entirely original as it is just another version of the Golden Rule), but I will point out that many self-professed (often professional!) Christians reject it as a model for their own way of life. Many atheists, on the other hand, live as though they believed it. 
 
 My point here is not to claim that atheists as a rule are more moral than Christians, just that atheists, Christians and believers of other faiths share a common morality that owes more to human nature than it does to any particular religious or theistic belief. The morals of Christians rest on human nature just as much as the morals of atheists.

 You are ashamed of being human? Personally, I don't think it's a matter of being proud or ashamed. It's what we are, and we can't avoid being who we are. I'm not going to patronise other humans beings for being childish, when there is so little difference between them and me... or you and them. Perhaps you have some exalted idea of what ideal humans should behave as, but your god behaves no better, according to scripture. We can always hope and try to be better than we are, but let's not excuse our actions by pretending we are children. We aren't.
 
 As for the provenance of human nature, you need look no further than evolution. Our present is rooted in our past.

 part of the problem is you generalizing on the state of man as a whole. maturity is on a continuum, like perfection; in a sense it can never be attained, only worked toward. we are still motivated largely by vanity and ego, but are much more responsible about environmental impact and relationship building, for instance, than we were years ago. man will never become "mature", not even by your standard.
 
 interestingly enough, if the nature of god as described in the bible is man's target to maturity, then expect regression rather than improvement

 First para; And why not ?
 
 Second para; And why is that, even if true ?

First para; And why not ?

 because, like i just said, maturity is a direction, not a destination. no matter how far east you travel, you'll never arrive at east. similarly, no matter how much you improve yourself, you'll never be perfect. and no matter how much you increase your maturity, you'll never be mature. 
 
 
Second para; And why is that, even if true ?

 following god as a role model is both impractical and self-destructive. god appears to operate constantly under double-standards, self contradictions and shifting paradigms. he'd command to his people "thou shalt not kill", for example, and a short while later command to the same people to initiate a war and utterly wipe out another clan or town. the most noteworthy characters of the bible clearly transgressed against god, yet were the most blessed. moses encouraged the israelites to steal, abraham was an adulterer, jacob was a deciever, both david and solomon were womanizers, samson was punished for cutting his hair, but not for living in fornication, and i could list many more "great men of god" who actually happened to be the rulers of israel at the time.
 
 so if we as a society were to adopt god's nature, minus the supernatural power, how would the world not be worse than it already is?

because, like i just said, maturity is a direction, not a destination. no matter how far east you travel, you'll never arrive at east. similarly, no matter how much you improve yourself, you'll never be perfect. and no matter how much you increase your maturity, you'll never be mature. 
 
 
 following god as a role model is both impractical and self-destructive. god appears to operate constantly under double-standards, self contradictions and shifting paradigms. he'd command to his people "thou shalt not kill", for example, and a short while later command to the same people to initiate a war and utterly wipe out another clan or town. the most noteworthy characters of the bible clearly transgressed against god, yet were the most blessed. moses encouraged the israelites to steal, abraham was an adulterer, jacob was a deciever, both david and solomon were womanizers, samson was punished for cutting his hair, but not for living in fornication, and i could list many more "great men of god" who actually happened to be the rulers of israel at the time.
 
 so if we as a society were to adopt god's nature, minus the supernatural power, how would the world not be worse than it already is?

 
 Quite agree that maturity is very probably a direction. However if we stand and look back can we see an improvement ? If so then we are going in the right direction. If we look forward can we see/glimpse areas where we can improve ? Are you saying that we can never go forward ? If so, I heartily disagree with you, I believe mankind has a very long road to go. Currently I would liken us to squabbling infants.
 
 If in your second para, you are believeing the bible as being literally true then I sympathise with you and there is not a lot of point about arguing as to who and how it was written for what purposes. If not, then I cannot see that following Jesus' commandments we can go far wrong.

Quite agree that maturity is very probably a direction. However if we stand and look back can we see an improvement ? If so then we are going in the right direction. If we look forward can we see/glimpse areas where we can improve ? Are you saying that we can never go forward ? If so, I heartily disagree with you, I believe mankind has a very long road to go. Currently I would liken us to squabbling infants.

 i wouldnt speculate too much about looking forward, but we can compare where we are today to where we were a few hundred years ago. there was an age past when we would link the presence of an old woman in a town to the crops being diseased, and drown or hang her. there was an age when diseased people were treated by burning them and there belongings. there was an age when your success in life was solely dependant on the family you were born into. so where we are today is definitely a step in the right direction.
 
 generally, the people today with the most influence are those who are highly motivated by self improvement and charity. there are more people who make a positive impact on the trends and culture of the world than those who make a negative impact, and there are far more people who have good intentions for the future of humanity than those who aim to see it destroyed. i would dare say that the very attitude of seeing the world as a bad place instead of a good place is the perspective that the destructive few adopt. how mature or childish the world is will always be a matter of opinion, and it reflects the character of the person with that opinion rater than the reality of the world itself
 
 
If in your second para, you are believeing the bible as being literally true then I sympathise with you and there is not a lot of point about arguing as to who and how it was written for what purposes. If not, then I cannot see that following Jesus' commandments we can go far wrong.

 what is the point of even considering the bible as any form of authority on anything if it was based on fiction? let's say jesus said "love your neighboor as yourself" and then said "i'm going to prepare a place for your, and i will come back to gather you unto me", are we expected to love our neighboors in anticipation of being rewarded with heaven when the basis of the condition was fictional to begin with? similarly, why would anybody believe that god gave moses ten commandments written on stone tablets if we arent supposed to take the bible literally? so were the commandments written by god himself? were there ever stone tablets? was god even involved in the process? if there is even a seed of truth in the accounts of the bible, how do we determine what they are? if were arent taking accounts to be literal, then are they fictional? parables? exagerrations? where are the actual parts that we should take seriously, and how do we tell the difference?
